content.description:
Start route off big rock in the lower pool. Doing the Splits across the water will be your first Crux. Climb right into dihedral over the water and follow a left leaning seam to a steep roof. Bolts get progressively run-out after the 5th bolt. Climb left side of roof through good holds and finish straight above the roof on a slab.

It's safer to Rap from the top to anchor right under the roof and then back to rock. Make sure to clip one strand of rope back into fixed draws for pulling the rope.
content.protection: 8 Bolts. Bots 5,3,1 are fixed for keeping your rope dry when pulling.
content.location: Route is located on the far most right side of Failsafe wall. Look for obvious "Thumb-print" looking roof.

content.description:
This multi-pitch, desert-tower-like trad extravaganza is just the ticket if you're starting to feel like a weenie for clipping so many bolts.  For extra value, make a campaign out of this and do Controversial Insert while you're up there.

As you might expect, this wide gear route doesn't get much traffic so test before yarding and helmets are advisable.

Attains nice position above the river.

P1.  5.9, 130'.  Follow a wide crack up the corner to an anchor.  The crux is in the first 30' above the starting block/pillar so you can blow most of your wide gear there.  To facilitate communication, we broke this into two pitches, belaying after 40', atop the starting block/pillar.

P2: 5.10, 100'.  Climb straight up easy cracks and a low-angle, right-facing corner until you encounter the crux, a 20' undercling/traverse along a wide fist crack.  An anchor follows shortly.

P3: We didn't do this as ML dissed it, doing it greatly complicates the descent and we weren't even clear where it went.

To descend: The rap from P2 to P1 is about 90'.  From P1 to the base about 130'.  Some jiggery-pokery required to keep ropes from getting soaked on the last rap.
content.protection: We took a single set of 1-7 Rocks, 1 ea yellow & red Alien, doubles up to #4 Camalot and 1 #5 C3 Camalot.  The #5 is only used on the first pitch and you could probably get by w/out it.
content.location: On the right/south sector of Failsafe Wall at the right side of an obvious 40' high block/pillar, on a small beach barely out of the river.

content.description: This route follows the obvious discontinuous finger crack to the right of the huge Flailsafe corner. It used to be mostly protected by gear (in addition to 4 bolts), but it has been retro-bolted. The crux comes high in the route and involves a boulder problem. If you're not too pumped, climb the final overhang on good jams to find better holds above.

An archetypical ORG route featuring continuous vertical crimping.  There is a thin technical crux past the 2nd bolt, then a rest, then some sustained 5.10 and a secondary crux getting to the anchors -- if you blow the last moves, scream loudly if you want your belayer to hear you.
content.location: On the left/upstream sector of Failsafe. The middle of three routes on the west facing wall.

content.description: Something of a generic ORG edge route which gets little traffic and appears to be in a runoff path and thus can be dirty, dusty and gritty.  Anchor the belayer or a fall will pull him/her into the stream.
content.location: One route right of the much superior Drill Rig.

content.description:
Featuring a beautiful splitter, this pitch is two stars by itself, but three in conjunction with the approach, the first pitch of Failsafe.

From the anchors atop Failsafe P1, climb straight up an easy crack for about 20', place gear w/ long runners, face traverse left for about 10' (5.8-9, no gear) and gain the bottom of the splitter.   The splitter starts as rattly fingers and quickly widens to good hands; which the patina on the wall around the crack is very smooth, the inside of the crack is as rough as a shredder JTree pitch -- tape may be advised.  Above the crack there is a steep slot with a tricky finger/fist wudge move.  A ledge and crusty sling anchors follow.  The slings don't offer much visual comfort so you might want to bring a knife and something to replace them with; the bolts they're attached to seemed fine.

While continuing from the anchor seemed feasible and even desirable, CI ends at this point with a 115' rap back to the anchor at the end of Failsafe P1.
content.protection: Double set of cams from .5 Camalot to #3 Camalot. 1 #4 Camalot.  We had some smaller gear including nuts but I don't think we used them.
content.location: Do the first pitch of Failsafe.

content.description:
This deserves to see some traffic.  A nice counterpart to it's neighbor Failsafe that is also, for almost it's entirety, on rock of similar quality. Characterized by techy steep crimping to start, tricky sequence reads in several places, and surprisingly pumpy climbing over it's length. Not a good warm weather or direct sun route as the rock is polished.

Start off the small fallen tree extending out over the lower pool.  The first bolt is high and a little right to direct the leader out into the void in the event of a fall.  Shorter people may need to use a short stick clip if they can't reach the bolt.  Years ago the tree wasn't there but it was pretty similar; bridging instead from the boulder to a high bolt across the void.  Mixed blessing, with the tree it's easier to clip the bolt and pull on but the tree could be a falling issue so a high first bolt is even more desirable.  The crux second bolt is close and not that hard to get to, the extra height provided by it should prevent any problems with the tree.

Once committed to pulling onto the wall acoss the void the game is on.  The crux is almost immediate, followed by several tricky to read boulder sequences.  Good stuff.
content.location: Immediately right of Failsafe.  Obvious, starts off the fallen tree that extends out into the void above the lower pool (tree is wedged between the boulder and the wall).  If the tree goes could still be started via bridging as was done originally.
